articles.headline: British Bank in $340 Million Settlement for Laundering
articles.snippet: New York’s top banking regulator had accused Standard Chartered of laundering $250 billion for Iranian clients and lying about it to authorities.
articles.abstract: New York’s top banking regulator had accused Standard Chartered of laundering $250 billion for Iranian clients and lying about it to authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standard Chartered, the British bank, has agreed to pay New York’s top banking regulator $340 million to settle claims that it laundered hundreds of billions of dollars in tainted money for Iran and lied to regulators.

articles.headline: Utility’s Role in Convention Tests Obama
articles.snippet: Efforts to free the Democratic convention from business and lobbyist support have prompted charges of hypocrisy from Republicans and grumbling among some Democrats.
articles.abstract: Efforts to free the Democratic convention from business and lobbyist support have prompted charges of hypocrisy from Republicans and grumbling among some Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When Charlotte first emerged as the top contender to host the Democratic convention, its lead cheerleader was James E. Rogers, the outspoken chief executive of the hometown utility, Duke Energy. He promised to be a public face and a private fund-raiser for the effort.

articles.headline: America’s Aversion to Taxes
articles.snippet: Though the nation’s fiscal challenge has taken center stage in the presidential campaign, raising more taxes from American families remains stubbornly off the table.
articles.abstract: Though the nation’s fiscal challenge has taken center stage in the presidential campaign, raising more taxes from American families remains stubbornly off the table.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is something to be said for universal health care systems.

articles.headline: Spanish Construction Rivals Battle on New York Turf
articles.snippet: Judlau Contracting and Dragados, partners working on the Long Island Rail Road extension project, have traded charges over who is responsible for a $250 million loss.
articles.abstract: Judlau Contracting and Dragados, partners working on the Long Island Rail Road extension project, have traded charges over who is responsible for a $250 million loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dripping canyons of New York City’s ever expanding network of train and subway tunnels would seem to be a far cry from the euro zone’s continuing financial debacle.

articles.headline: Importing Russia’s Top Gun
articles.snippet: As Russia’s military has cut back Kalashnikov purchases, American enthusiasts have started buying civilian versions of weapons manufactured by the same factory.
articles.abstract: As Russia’s military has cut back Kalashnikov purchases, American enthusiasts have started buying civilian versions of weapons manufactured by the same factory.
articles.lead_paragraph: IZHEVSK, Russia — The nickname of this town, home of the factory that makes Kalashnikov rifles, is the “Armory of Russia.” Over the years, it has armed a good number of other countries, too, as the lathes and presses of the Izhevsk Machine Works clanged around the clock to forge AK-47s and similar guns for insurgents and armies around the world.

articles.headline: Grandmas Grow Gold in Swaziland
articles.snippet: Many of the marijuana-farming grandmothers of Swaziland, who supply South Africa’s drug market, started growing to support the offspring their children left behind when they died.
articles.abstract: Many of the marijuana-farming grandmothers of Swaziland, who supply South Africa’s drug market, started growing to support the offspring their children left behind when they died.
articles.lead_paragraph: PIGGS PEAK, Swaziland — After her daughters died, Khathazile took in her 11 orphaned grandchildren without hesitation. It is what a gogo, or grandmother, does in a country where the world’s highest H.I.V. infection rate has left a sea of motherless children.

articles.headline: Two-Way Jabs on Medicare Recast Races for Congress
articles.snippet: A fight over the health care program for older Americans is intensifying in House and Senate races after Representative Paul D. Ryan’s selection as Mitt Romney’s running mate.
articles.abstract: A fight over the health care program for older Americans is intensifying in House and Senate races after Representative Paul D. Ryan’s selection as Mitt Romney’s running mate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one tight Florida House race, a hastily assembled TV commercial to begin airing Wednesday takes aim at a top target of Democrats, highlighting his votes “to end Medicare as we know it.”

articles.headline: Frustrations of Air Travel Push Passengers to Amtrak
articles.snippet: Passengers weary of the security and delays of airports are flocking to trains, which now dominate commercial travel in the Boston-Washington corridor.
articles.abstract: Passengers weary of the security and delays of airports are flocking to trains, which now dominate commercial travel in the Boston-Washington corridor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long a punch line for harried Northeast travelers, Amtrak has come to dominate commercial travel in the corridor connecting Washington, New York and Boston, and this summer its trains are packed.

articles.headline: A Tablet Straining to Do It All
articles.snippet: Samsung’s new iPad rival, the Galaxy Note 10.1, is loaded with features, but not all are well organized or practical.
articles.abstract: Samsung’s new iPad rival, the Galaxy Note 10.1, is loaded with features, but not all are well organized or practical.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hot news in Silicon Valley legal circles these days is Apple’s titanic lawsuit against Samsung. Apple maintains that Samsung pilfered some of its iPhone and iPad designs when creating the Samsung Galaxy series of phones and tablets.
